metadata.title: LA-CALC-4.5 Graphing Using Derivatives
metadata.creator: Asseel
metadata.abstract: The goal of this module is to be able to draw graphs with tools other than a table of values. Following the steps, we will be able to have an idea of functions should be drawn with a high-level of abstraction.

stack.name: stack1
stack.p: Using concepts from concavity, critical points and inflection points, we are able to graph functions efficiently without the use of a graphing calculator. This is just one of the many uses of derivatives. In this module we will look at graphing polynomial functions step-by-step.

stack.name: stack1
stack.p: Steps for Sketching a Function $ f( x ) $

stack.name: stepStack
stack.p: Determine the domain of the function

stack.name: cont
stack.p: To find the domain of a given function $ f ( x ) $, we have to find if there are any values for x such that $ f ( x ) $ is undefined.
If there are no such values where the value of y is undefined for a given x, then we can simply state the domain as $ x \in R $

If there are x values that make $ f ( x ) $ undefined, we must determine what that value is. For an example, a function with a fraction such as $ f ( x ) = \frac{2}{x-5} $ will have an undefined point at $ x = 5 $. In this case, our domain would be $ \{ x \in R | x \neq 5 \} $ or $ (-\infty , 5 ) \cup ( 5 , \infty) $

stack.p: To determine the x and the y intercept of $ f ( x ) $, simply determine what value (if any) is obtained from substituting $ x = 0 $ and $ y = 0 $.
To find the y intercept, plug in $ x = 0 $ and solve. Here is an example:
To find the x intercept, plug in $ f ( x ) = 0 $ and solve. Here is an example:

stack.p: Find all critical points of the function

stack.name: cont
stack.p: To determine critical points, determine where $ f'( x ) = 0 $. That is, determine where the first derivative is equal to zero. Here's an example

Note: Some critical points can be minima and maxima if we can also determine whether the function is concaving upward or downward at the critical point. To find out how to determine concavity, see the Step 7.

stack.p: Find the second derivative of $ f ( x ) $

stack.name: cont
stack.p: To determine the second derivative, simply derive the first derivative. This will be useful to determine the concavity of a function. Here's an example:

stack.name: stepStack
stack.p: Determine points of interest from $ f''( x ) $

stack.name: cont
stack.p: To determine points of interest, find out when $ f''( x ) = 0 $. That is, find out when the second derivative is equal to zero. Here's an example:

button.name: btn

stack.name: stepStack
stack.p: Determine the concavity from the points of interest

stack.name: cont
stack.p: To determine the concavity from any points of interest, we have to find the value of $ f''( x ) $ to the left and to the right of any points of interest. If $ f''( x ) $ is positive on both sides, we have an area of the graph where the function is concaving upwards. If $ f''( x ) $ is negative, we have an area of the graph where the function is concaving downwards. If we have a positive value on one side and a negative value on another, then the point is an inflection point.

Therefore we can determine that this point is an inflection point. It is concaving downwards as $ x \rightarrow \frac{-2}{15} $ from the left and is concaving upwards as $ x \rightarrow \frac{-2}{15} $ from the right

button.name: btn

stack.name: cont
stack.p: Use all the information from the steps above to graph the function $ f( x ) = 5x^3+x^2 $
y-intercept at $ f( x ) = 0 $. Plug this into $ f ( x ) $ and we have point $ ( 0, 0 ) $
x-intercept at $ x = \frac{-1}{5} $ Plug this into $ f ( x ) $ and we have point $ ( \frac{-1}{5} , 0 ) $

Critical Point(s): $ x = \frac{-2}{15} $ Plug this into $ f ( x ) $ and we have point $ ( -0.1333, 0.0059 ) $. Since we have determined that the function is concaving downward at this critical point, this is a local maximum.
When $ x < \frac{-2}{15} $ the function concaves downwards
When $ x > \frac{-2}{15} $ the function concaves upwards.

We have two critical points, one at x = 1 and another at x = 0. We will determine if these are minima or maxima points when determining the second derivative.

stack.name: cont
stack.p: Therefore this point is an inflection point. It is concaving downwards as $ x \rightarrow \frac{2}{3} $ from the left and is concaving upwards as $ x \rightarrow \frac{2}{3} $ from the right
We can also determine whether our critical points are maxima or minima by plugging it into our second derivative.
Our two critical points were $ x = 0 $ and $ x = 1 $
$ f''( 1 ) = 12. $ We know that this is concave upwards
$ f''( 0 ) = 0. $ This might be another inflection point. We can determine this by checking to the left and to the right of $ f( 0 ) $
Therefore this point is also another inflection point. It is concaving upwards to the left and concaving downwards from the right

Inflection Point(s): $ x = 0 $ Plug this into $ f ( x ) $ and we have point $ ( 0, 2 ) $. The function concaves upwards to the left and downwards to the right of this point.
